Award.AwardTitle: Examination of the Strength and Dilatancy of Granular Materials using 3D Printed Soil

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The determination of the strength and stiffness of sands and gravels is a very important component of the design and construction of many civil engineering structures such as building and bridge foundations, levees, earth dams and retaining walls. Geotechnical engineers know that strength and stiffness are a function of grain shape and texture, as well as the density of the soil and the pressure it is subjected to. However, natural sands and gravels vary in mineralogy, surface roughness, size distribution, and particle shape making it very difficult to gain a clear understanding of how these variables affect the soil?s engineering properties. This research seeks to apply a novel technology, 3D printing, to a classical soil mechanics problem to reexamine soil strength in a way that is not possible with natural soils. 3D printed particles maintain the same material and surface properties even when the particle shape or size distribution is varied. This feature allows for the direct influence of particle shape to be examined. Laboratory experiments on 3D printed granular particles will be used to refine current theories of soil behavior. Being able to better predict the behavior of sands and gravels on a description of shape would greatly advance the state-of-art in the fields of soil mechanics, geotechnical engineering, pavement materials, and material handling processes. In addition, the use of 3D printed soil provides a synergistic approach to teaching fundamental soil behavior at the undergraduate and graduate levels.

Critical state soil mechanics provides a useful framework for analyzing soil behavior, but the need for large soil databases and the lack of a unique relationship between dilatancy and strength hinders its more-wide acceptance among practitioners and undergraduate soil mechanics classes. Because the critical state shearing angle is mostly dependent on mineralogy, the peak angle of shearing resistance depends on a dilatancy-related component of strength, and thus it depends on shape. This research tests the hypothesis that 3D printed particles can be used as an analog granular soil to investigate the relationship between dilatancy and strength by systematically varying shape while keeping the material properties the same. Not only will the experimental data be useful to demonstrate this relationship, but it will also be instrumental in the validation of discrete element method (DEM) models which can be used to examine the particle-scale response. Understanding the fundamental behavior in a dilatancy context will contribute to an increased understanding of numerous, more complex geotechnical problems including: liquefaction, pile side friction, bearing capacity, slope stability, and in situ testing (Cone Penetrometer Test, Standard Penetration Test).

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES
REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of the proposed research was to determine whether 3D printed particles could be used as an analogue granular soil to define a universal relationship between dilatancy and strength by separating out the contribution arising from particle shape. Two additive manufacturing (AM) devices were selected from the large number of available technologies based on part strength, part stiffness, cost, and overall material behavior. The ideal technology was found to be a binder jetting gypsum powder 3D printer in which particles were post-processed with an epoxy infiltrant. This was the stiffest of the materials tested, resulting in a brittle failure and material properties similar to a sandstone or a soft to medium-soft limestone. Although the material properties and overall behavior were within the targeted range, it was determined that the gypsum-epoxy composite was not waterproof and a significant reduction of strength occurred when it was submerged in water for extended periods of time. For this reason, a stereolithography (SLA) device which used a photopolymer material which is thermal and UV light cured was also investigated. This material was less stiff than the gypsum-epoxy composite and it failed in a much more ductile response; however, it was shown to have sufficient strength and stiffness for the proposed application. For each material, the research team was able to develop new post-processing procedures which were shown to generate particles with greater strength and stiffness when compared to the manufactures’ specifications. These procedures were also shown to greatly improve the quality control and repeatability of generating similar specimens, two items which were found to be very important in this study. Two peer-reviewed journal articles were submitted to disseminate these processes and they have been accepted for publication in the Rapid Prototyping Journal.

Once the specimens were developed and characterized, they were tested in a typical geotechnical laboratory test to determine their ability to be used as an analogue soil. The results showed that the 3D printed granular materials behaved similar to sands in terms of their stress-strain and volumetric responses. The ability to use 3D printed soils will now allow for particle shape and size to be singled out, so that a direct examination of their influence on strength can be made. This is not possible with any other type of natural material and to date, there are no other manufactured materials capable of being used for this type of study.  Not only will the experimental data be useful to demonstrate this relationship, but it will also be instrumental in the validation of discrete element method models.  Understanding the fundamental behavior of granular soils will contribute to increased understanding of numerous complex geotechnical problems including: liquefaction, pile side friction, bearing capacity, slope stability, and in situ testing (Cone Penetrometer Test, Standard Penetration Test).  This research also has the ability to shed light on similar dilatancy and strength behavior observed in asphalt, as well as material handling processes.

In addition to the advancement of the field of soil mechanics and geotechnical engineering, the use of 3D printed analogue soil provides a novel and synergistic approach to teaching fundamental soil behavior.  The PI is currently developing a teaching tool based on the findings of this research and will make it available on her website for students and other professors.  This resource will include the experimental data and analysis, along with videos and schematics of simple friction/dilatancy demonstrations.  Also, 3D printed models will be generated and used within the PI’s soil mechanics class to help demonstrate the relationship between interparticle friction, dilatancy, and overall soil strength.

POR.POR_COPY_TXT: The goal of the proposed research was to determine whether 3D printed particles could be used as an analogue granular soil to define a universal relationship between dilatancy and strength by separating out the contribution arising from particle shape. Two additive manufacturing (AM) devices were selected from the large number of available technologies based on part strength, part stiffness, cost, and overall material behavior. For each material, the research team was able to develop new post-processing procedures which were shown to generate particles with greater strength and stiffness when compared to the manufactures? specifications. Two peer-reviewed journal articles were submitted to disseminate these processes and they have been accepted for publication in the Rapid Prototyping Journal. Once the specimens were developed and characterized, they were tested in a typical geotechnical laboratory test to determine their ability to be used as an analogue soil. The results showed that the 3D printed granular materials behaved similar to sands in terms of their stress-strain and volumetric responses. The ability to use 3D printed soils will now allow for particle shape and size to be singled out, so that a direct examination of their influence on strength can be made. This is not possible with any other type of natural material and to date, there are no other manufactured materials capable of being used for this type of study. Understanding the fundamental behavior of granular soils will contribute to increased understanding of numerous complex geotechnical problems including: liquefaction, pile side friction, bearing capacity, slope stability, and in situ testing (Cone Penetrometer Test, Standard Penetration Test). This research also has the ability to shed light on similar dilatancy and strength behavior observed in asphalt, as well as material handling processes. In addition to the advancement of the field of soil mechanics and geotechnical engineering, the use of 3D printed analogue soil provides a novel and synergistic approach to teaching fundamental soil behavior. The PI is currently developing a teaching tool based on the findings of this research and will make it available on her website for students and other professors. This resource will include the experimental data and analysis, along with videos and schematics of simple friction/dilatancy demonstrations. Also, 3D printed models will be generated and used within the PI?s soil mechanics class to help demonstrate the relationship between interparticle friction, dilatancy, and overall soil strength.
